name: NewYorker
text: “In many ways, the whole Trump Presidency can be encapsulated in the past few days and weeks,” @sbg1 writes. “It is narcissism, recklessness, and disregard for the public good—and for democracy itself.” https://t.co/WIfaro32B9

name: NewYorker
text:
A new report by Bright Line Watch, a group that monitors threats to democratic practices, reveals a "very real threat of significant political violence" in the aftermath of the election.
https://t.co/hNSS1lXXcb

name: NewYorker
text:
Saidiya Hartman’s latest book, “Wayward Lives, Beautiful Experiments,” blends history and fiction to chronicle the sexual and gender rebellions of young Black women in the 20th century.
https://t.co/9eVCTx30iK

name: NewYorker
text: How e-mails and records reveal that a Republican Party operative may have unconstitutionally used race data to draw congressional districts in 2016, resulting in a racial gerrymander. https://t.co/22g1qkuwqX

name: NewYorker
text: “The Chinese lockdown was more intense than almost anywhere else in the world,” writes Peter Hessler, who teaches at Sichuan University. It wasn’t unheard-of for a door to be sealed shut during contact-tracing if a family was suspected of exposure. https://t.co/4SAx43zaVJ

name: NewYorker
text: Authorities believe that Pia Farrenkopf died in 2009. She kept paying her bills until 2014. https://t.co/YK67EAYWQT

name: NewYorker
text: An American President attacking American democracy in advance of an election has simply never been seen before. But Donald Trump continues to do it every day, in the final run-up to November 3rd. https://t.co/vcDh0h7vA1

name: NewYorker
text: To many in Maine, Susan Collins’s recent record has felt like a failure to meet the moment. https://t.co/jwojzyGWpq

name: NewYorker
text: “Life and death were simple and whole, / No need for explanation, let alone hope.” A poem by @SashaHemon. https://t.co/pQFQCNiWHw

name: NewYorker
text: “We’ve spent 50 years talking about child care as if it were a personal problem, and we’re finally talking about it as a social problem and realizing how important it is for society,” @BetseyStevenson said. https://t.co/sZXHxOumSS

name: NewYorker
text: “ ‘Time’ is a sort of collective autobiography, a story of a family that is both unhappy in a way that many families, many Black families, are unhappy, and happy in its own way, because of its fierce devotion to remaining together,” @tnyfrontrow writes. https://t.co/XUV7bUAEQ0

name: NewYorker
text: What if you started itching—and couldn’t stop? #NewYorkerArchive https://t.co/RDdiwbJ5OF

name: NewYorker
text:
The educational podcast "You're Wrong About" presents a kind of Schadenfreude theatre; you get to hear someone get absolutely schooled, in real time, as they make the journey from ignorance to insight.
https://t.co/1m6fopnp3c

name: NewYorker
text:
Hundreds of political scientists fear that, if Donald Trump loses the election, he may encourage political violence.
https://t.co/sQdjiskVv2

name: NewYorker
text: “I Burn Paris,” a sensation when it was first published, in 1928, describes a contagion infecting and paralyzing a large metropolis. It now feels darkly prophetic—but are its echoes with the present day merely superficial?  https://t.co/rFsrpjfhQM

name: NewYorker
text: Hundreds of pages of e-mails, transcripts, and other documents obtained by The New Yorker corroborate the scope of a C.I.A. scheme to whitewash information gathered via secret surveillance. @RonanFarrow reports. https://t.co/JayGfXDwgL

name: NewYorker
text: River for which a “monstrous” lizard is named: four letters. https://t.co/giub7mVijA

name: NewYorker
text: In an interview with @IChotiner, the activist and linguist Noam Chomsky expressed serious concerns about the future of American democracy, although, in his view, it “was never much to write home about.” https://t.co/3z9L6sRFap
